bill_title: establish a presumption regarding occupational diseases affecting firefighters.

bill_versions.bill_text: FOR AN ACT ENTITLED, An Act to establish a presumption regarding occupational diseases affecting firefighters. BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF SOUTH DAKOTA: Section 1. That chapter 62-8 be amended by adding thereto a NEW SECTION to read as follows: For any firefighter as defined by § 13-55-21 who is covered by the provisions of this chapter, there is a prima facie presumption that any of the following is an occupational disease covered by this chapter: (1) Any respiratory disease; (2) Any heart problem that is experienced within seventy-two hours of exposure to smoke, fumes, or toxic substances; and (3) Any cancer. This presumption of an occupational disease may be rebutted by a preponderance of the evidence controverting the presumption. Section 2. That chapter 62-8 be amended by adding thereto a NEW SECTION to read as follows: The presumption with regard to cancer established pursuant to this Act applies only to any active or former firefighter who has cancer that develops or manifests itself after the firefighter has served at least five years and who was given a qualifying medical examination upon becoming a firefighter that showed no evidence of cancer. The presumption only applies to primary brain cancer, malignant melanoma, leukemia, non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, bladder cancer, ureter cancer, and kidney cancer.

FOR AN ACT ENTITLED, An Act to establish a presumption regarding occupational diseases affecting firefighters. BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF SOUTH DAKOTA: Section 1. That chapter 62-8 be amended by adding thereto a NEW SECTION to read as follows: For any firefighter who is a full-time member of a paid fire department and who is covered by the provisions of this chapter, there is a prima facie presumption that any of the following is an occupational disease covered by this chapter: (1) Any respiratory disease; (2) Any heart problem that is experienced within seventy-two hours of exposure to smoke, fumes, or toxic substances; and (3) Any cancer as listed in section 2 of this Act. This presumption of an occupational disease may be rebutted by a preponderance of the evidence controverting the presumption. Section 2. That chapter 62-8 be amended by adding thereto a NEW SECTION to read as follows: The presumption with regard to cancer established pursuant to this Act applies only to any active or former firefighter who has cancer that develops or manifests itself after the firefighter has served at least five years and who was given a qualifying medical examination upon becoming a firefighter that showed no evidence of cancer. The presumption only applies to primary brain cancer, malignant melanoma, leukemia, non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, bladder cancer, ureter cancer, and kidney cancer.
